user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_BSP_Setup:
```c
void UT_BSP_Setup(void)
{
    uint8        UserShift;
    uint32       ArgC;
    char *const *ArgV;

    memset(&BSP_UT_Global, 0, sizeof(BSP_UT_Global));

    UserShift = UTASSERT_CASETYPE_NONE;
    ArgC      = OS_BSP_GetArgC();
    if (ArgC > 0)
    {
        ArgV = OS_BSP_GetArgV();
        while (ArgC > 0)
        {
            --ArgC;

            if (strcmp(ArgV[0], "-d") == 0)
            {
                UserShift = UTASSERT_CASETYPE_DEBUG;
            }
            if (strcmp(ArgV[0], "-q") == 0)
            {
                UserShift = UTASSERT_CASETYPE_FAILURE;
            }
            if (strcmp(ArgV[0], "-v") == 0 && ArgC > 0)
            {
                --ArgC;
                UserShift = strtoul(ArgV[1], NULL, 0);
                ++ArgV;
            }

            ++ArgV;
        }
    }

    if (UserShift == UTASSERT_CASETYPE_NONE || UserShift >= UTASSERT_CASETYPE_MAX)
    {
        UserShift = UTASSERT_CASETYPE_PASS;
    }

    BSP_UT_Global.CurrVerbosity = (2 << UserShift) - 1;

    UT_BSP_DoText(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_BEGIN, "UNIT TEST");
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Only the ArgV-related code needs investigation for Rule 8.13. The declaration 'char *const *ArgV' and its assignment from OS_BSP_GetArgV(), the indexed uses ArgV[0]/ArgV[1] passed to strcmp/strtoul, and the pointer arithmetic (++ArgV) all involve pointers to non-const character data used in read-only contexts; these should be checked to see if the pointed-to type can be const-qualified (for example const char * const *). Other fragments in the function do not involve pointers that should be const-qualified (numeric variables, memset on a struct object, string literal passed to UT_BSP_DoText is a literal and not a mutable buffer here), so they are not relevant to Rule 8.13 and do not need investigation.
